original_data.question: A 35-year-old woman presents to the office because she has felt a small painless mass in her neck which has been slowly growing. She has no relevant past medical history. Her vital signs are within normal limits. On physical exam of the thyroid gland, a solitary nodule is palpated. It is fixed to the surrounding tissues and nontender. TSH is normal, and antithyroid antibodies are negative. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?

model_response:
The incidence of thyroid carcinoma has been increasing in recent years. In this patient, the presence of a solitary thyroid nodule suggests a higher chance of malignancy. Follicular carcinoma is a malignancy that arises from follicular cells. It is usually not associated with a palpable nodule. Papillary carcinoma is the most common thyroid malignancy and is usually associated with a palpable nodule. Hashimoto thyroiditis is a common cause of a painless thyroid nodule. It is associated with an enlarged gland and an elevated TSH. Endemic goiter is usually associated with an enlarged thyroid gland and is caused by iodine deficiency.

Answer: OPTION C IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Human females as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
A benign or malignant pathologic structure in any part of the body, resulting from a neoplastic accumulation of cells, inflammatory cells, or cystic changes.
The part of a human or animal body connecting the HEAD to the rest of the body.
An indication that something is growing at a slow rate.
A record of a patient's background regarding health and the occurrence of disease events of the individual. In addition, personal medical history may be a variable in epidemiologic studies.
Actions performed to measure temperature, pulse, respirations, and blood pressure
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.

A highly vascularized endocrine gland consisting of two lobes joined by a thin band of tissue with one lobe on each side of the TRACHEA. It secretes THYROID HORMONES from the follicular cells and CALCITONIN from the parafollicular cells thereby regulating METABOLISM and CALCIUM level in blood, respectively.
Extending on all sides of simultaneously; encircling.

Collections of differentiated CELLS, such as EPITHELIUM; CONNECTIVE TISSUE; MUSCLES; and NERVE TISSUE. Tissues are cooperatively arranged to form organs with specialized functions such as RESPIRATION; DIGESTION; REPRODUCTION; MOVEMENT; and others.

A glycoprotein hormone secreted by the adenohypophysis (PITUITARY GLAND, ANTERIOR). Thyrotropin stimulates THYROID GLAND by increasing the iodide transport, synthesis and release of thyroid hormones (THYROXINE and TRIIODOTHYRONINE). Thyrotropin consists of two noncovalently linked subunits, alpha and beta. Within a species, the alpha subunit is common in the pituitary glycoprotein hormones (TSH; LUTEINIZING HORMONE and FSH), but the beta subunit is unique and confers its biological specificity.
Antibodies which react with the individual structural determinants (idiotopes) on the variable region of other antibodies.

An absence finding of the specified component / analyte, organism or clinical sign based on the established threshold of the performed test or procedure.

\[Note: Negative does not necessarily imply the complete absence of the specified item.\]
